title: The exhaustion of managing everything
teaser: You're monitoring, planning, protecting. But the anxiety isn't easing—it's multiplying.
framework: Matthew 6:33 - Seek first the kingdom... and all these things will be added

panels.heading: THE WEIGHT OF WATCHFULNESS
panels.content:
You wake up and reach for your phone.

Before your feet hit the floor, you're scrolling. Checking what happened overnight. Scanning for threats. Reading headlines that spike your cortisol.

This is how you start every day: **on high alert.**

You tell yourself it's responsible. Staying informed. Being prepared. Knowing what's happening so you can protect yourself and the people you love.

But really, you're trying to manage chaos.

And the chaos is winning.

Because no matter how much you monitor, the world keeps spiraling. And your anxiety keeps growing.

panels.heading: THE DOOMSCROLL LOOP
panels.content:
You can't stop scrolling.

One article becomes ten. One thread becomes an hour. You're not even reading anymore—you're just consuming, feeding the need to know more.

Political violence. Economic instability. Civil unrest. Every headline confirms your worst fears: **the world is out of control.**

And if the world is out of control, you need to control something. Your environment. Your information. Your response.

So you keep scrolling. Planning. Arguing. Defending.

But here's the truth: **the more you try to manage the chaos, the more the chaos manages you.**

panels.heading: THE BURDEN OF CONTINGENCY PLANS
panels.content:
It's not just the news. It's everything.

You're running through scenarios in your head. What if the economy crashes? What if violence spreads to your city? What if you lose your job?

You stock supplies. You calculate budgets. You create backup plans for the backup plans.

This is what happens when you believe peace comes from preparedness: **you're always preparing, never at peace.**

Because there's always one more contingency you haven't planned for. One more threat you haven't mitigated. One more variable you can't control.

The anxiety doesn't ease. It multiplies.

And you're carrying a weight you were never meant to bear.

illustration.description: Dithered image of person buried under stacks of papers/plans or shoulders weighed down by chains

panels.heading: WHAT JESUS SAID ABOUT WORRY
panels.content:
In the middle of Roman occupation—political violence, economic exploitation, constant instability—Jesus told anxious people:

**"Who of you by worrying can add a single hour to your life?"**

It's almost offensive. Of course I'm worried. Look at the world.

But Jesus wasn't dismissing their fear. He was exposing the futility of their strategy.

Worry doesn't protect you. Planning for every disaster doesn't bring peace. Controlling your environment doesn't stop chaos.

All it does is exhaust you.

Jesus wasn't saying, "Don't care about your life." He was saying, **"Stop trying to secure it through control. You can't."**

panels.heading: THE ALTERNATIVE TO ANXIETY
panels.content:
Jesus offered something radical to people drowning in worry:

**"Look at the birds of the air; they do not sow or reap or store away in barns, and yet your heavenly Father feeds them. Are you not much more valuable than they?"**

He wasn't saying, "Be passive. Don't work. Don't plan."

He was saying: **Your value isn't dependent on your ability to control outcomes.**

God cares for you. Not because you've managed everything perfectly. But because you're His.

The anxiety of control says: If I don't hold it together, everything falls apart.

The peace of the kingdom says: God holds it together. You can let go.

panels.heading: THE INVITATION
panels.content:
God,

I'm exhausted from managing everything.

I wake up anxious. I scroll compulsively. I plan obsessively. I'm trying to control what I can't control.

And it's breaking me.

You say I can't add a single hour to my life by worrying. You're right. But I don't know how to stop.

Teach me to release the weight. To trust that You hold what I can't.

I'm tired of carrying this. Help me let go.

Amen.
